comments.body: This appears to assume homogeneous clusters, which is true now, but not something that I want to make a requirement.
That's why it is in the experimental api, once we will be moving it to the stable api we can change it so it better fits heterogeneous clusters.
I think that until we have heterogeneous cluster it's easier for the user to provide number of nodes instead of computing number of cores/amount of memory.

Even using number of nodes, this seems useless without minimum requirements on node size. 

min and max should be optional and have default values.
Is it possible to have multiple of these resources in the cluster?
Once we have the metrics APIs we should ensure the terminology is consistent.
CPU should be all uppercase. It's an acronym.
Everywhere else we spell out Memory.
Typo: od
CPU, not CPUs

Do you really need fractional percentages? We're using strings in Deployment, such as "25%".

Also, "value" is pretty uninformative.
JSON field name and Go field name should not be difference except in capitalization. Please read the API conventions. Though we may break the APIs, even experimental has standards.
Should also be plural, to match "resources" and other lists and maps in the API.
Name doesn't match the pattern of the horizontal pod autoscaler. This doesn't create clusters, it creates nodes.
Ok, what about HorizontalNodeAutoscaler?
That would be better, but I reserve the right to ask it to be changed again when I can make more time to think about it.
Full POSIX or the RE2-subset thereof?

The way i understand this RE2 is close to what perl does (and the normal Compile of golang). I wanted to allow POSIX and let the loadbalancer choose. Haproxy does POSIX. The differences are small enough that I don't _think_ it should matter, and using POSIX gives me a nice ieee doc to reference. Correct me and ill change.
Is the purpose of this to help users outside the cluster find servers inside the cluster, or is it to help users inside the cluster find servers outside the cluster?
If the former, please make the comment clearer. If the latter, this should be called "Egress".

Seems pretty obvious by the comment that it's trying to allow external-to-internal access. Tho if you have subdivision of internal networks along namespaces you might also need it for internal pods to talk to services in another namespaces. Internal-to-internal technically isn't really Egress tho, even if you have to go out through some non-k8s networking or load balancer.

I think the primary use case was for the networking abstraction layer that k8s sits on to create load balancers, network routes, proxies, and/or port forwarding for external-to-internal traffic.
Thanks-- I may just be dense but I find this description _much_ clearer!
This is a long-winded way of saying it is a DNS_SUBDOMAIN, which we have specced elsewhere.
wait, a string with ip is also a subdomain right?

hmm, technically yes but that is a valid hostname, but no TLD is purely
numeric.  If we're asserting that this is a hostname field and someone
enters an IP, we 're going to do a DNS lookup on it.

On Fri, Sep 25, 2015 at 5:44 PM, Prashanth B notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In pkg/apis/experimental/types.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14459#discussion_r40487631
> :
> 
> > @@ -508,35 +511,70 @@ type IngressStatus struct {
> >     LoadBalancer api.LoadBalancerStatus `json:"loadBalancer,omitempty"`
> >  }
> > 
> > -// IngressRule represents the rules mapping the paths under a specified host to the related backend services.
> > -type IngressRule struct {
> > -   // Host is the fully qualified domain name of a network host, or its IP
> > -   // address as a set of four decimal digit groups separated by ".".
> > -   // Conforms to RFC 1738.
> >   +// IngressHost represents the rules mapping the paths under a specified host to
> >   +// the related backend services.
> >   +type IngressHost struct {
> > -   // Host is the fully qualified domain name of a network host, as defined
> 
> wait, a string with ip is also a subdomain right?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14459/files#r40487631.
I'm validating against the ip case also, because I think in most cases if someone puts an ip in there they don't expect a dns lookup
Can I get a TODO to add some sort of claim - we just added the ability to specify the LBIP in the existing Service struct, and now you're going to introduce L7 with the same limitation :)
I have add the TODO to identify that may add LBIP later.
